children.value: This notebook is intends to build off of the
Create a list of input paths for a collection of NetCDF files stored on the cloud.
Create virtual datasets for each input datasets
Combine the virtual datasets using combine_nested
In the section below, set the
depending if you want this notebook to process the full file list. If set to
, then a subset of the file list will be processed (Recommended)
In our imports block we are using similar imports to the
Basics of virtual Zarr stores tutorial
for reading and writing to remote file systems
will be used to generate the virtual Zarr store

import fsspec
import xarray as xr
from virtualizarr import open_virtual_dataset
Create a File Pattern from a list of  input NetCDF files

children.label: Create a File Pattern from a list of  input NetCDF files

children.value: Below we will create a list of input files we want to virtualize. In the
Basics of virtual Zarr stores tutorial
, we looked at a single file of climate downscaled data over Southern Alaska. In this example, we will build off of that work and use
to combine multiple NetCDF files of this dataset into a virtual dataset that can be read as if it were a
method to create a list of files matching a file pattern. We supply the base url of
public bucket, for daily rcp85 ccsm downscaled data for the year 2060. After this base url, we tacked on
, which acts as a wildcard for all the files in the directory. We should expect 365 daily
Finally, we are appending the string
to the list of return files. This will ensure the list of files we get back are
urls and can be read by

# Initiate fsspec filesystems for reading and writing
fs_read = fsspec.filesystem("s3", anon=True, skip_instance_cache=True)

# Retrieve list of available days in archive for the year 2060.
files_paths = fs_read.glob("s3://wrf-se-ak-ar5/ccsm/rcp85/daily/2060/*")

# Here we prepend the prefix 's3://', which points to AWS.
files_paths = sorted(["s3://" + f for f in files_paths])
As a quick check, it looks like we have a list 365 file paths, which should be a year of downscaled climte data.

children.label: As a quick check, it looks like we have a list 365 file paths, which should be a year of downscaled climte data.

children.value:
# If the subset_flag == True (default), the list of input files will
# be subset to speed up the processing
if subset_flag:
    files_paths = files_paths[0:4]
Optional: If you want to examine one NetCDF files before creating the
index, try uncommenting this code snippet below.

children.label: Optional: If you want to examine one NetCDF files before creating the Kerchunk index, try uncommenting this code snippet below.

children.value:
## Note: Optional piece of code to view one of the NetCDFs

# import s3fs

# fs = fsspec.filesystem("s3",anon=True)
# ds = xr.open_dataset(fs.open(file_pattern[0]))
Create virtual datasets for every file in the

children.label: Create virtual datasets for every file in the File_Pattern list

children.value: Now that we have a list of NetCDF files, we can use
to create virtual datasets for each one of these.
In the cell below, we are creating a dictionary of
filesystem. Details on this can be found in the
Basics of virtual Zarr stores tutorial

In the cell below, we are reusing some of the functionality from the previous tutorial.
First we are defining a function named:
Creates a simplified filename using some string slicing.
Uses the local filesystem created with
function we created, we have a simple
loop that iterates through our list of
file urls and passes them to our
function, which appends the name of each
reference file to a list named
After we have generated a virtual dataset for each
file, we can combine these into a single virtual dataset using Xarray’s

combined_vds = xr.combine_nested(
    virtual_datasets, concat_dim=["Time"], coords="minimal", compat="override"
)
combined_vds

children.value: Write combined virtual dataset to a Kerchunk JSON for future use

children.label: Write combined virtual dataset to a Kerchunk JSON for future use

children.value: If we want to keep the combined reference information in memory as well as write the file to
, we can run the code snippet below.
Now that we have built a virtual dataset using
, we can read all of those original
files as if they were a single
**Since we saved the combined virtual dataset, this work doesn’t have to be repeated for anyone else to use this dataset. All they need is to pass the reference file storing the virtual dataset to
and it is as if they had a
Open combined virtual dataset with Kerchunk

children.label: Open combined virtual dataset with Kerchunk

children.value:
# We once again need to provide information for fsspec to access the remote file
storage_options = dict(
    remote_protocol="s3", remote_options=dict(anon=True), skip_instance_cache=True
)
# We will use the "kerchunk" engine in `xr.open_dataset` and pass the `storage_options` to the `kerchunk` engine through `backend_kwargs`
ds = xr.open_dataset(
    output_fname,
    engine="kerchunk",
    backend_kwargs={"storage_options": storage_options},
)
ds
Plot a slice of the dataset

children.label: Plot a slice of the dataset

children.value: to select a single time slice of the dataset and plot a map of snow cover over South East Alaska.
